DataElement.preferredName: Tumor Identifier Domain Tumor Identifier Location Malignant Neoplasm Description Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The locational description of the malignant tumor as related to a biopsy, denoting if said tumor was primary versus metastatic.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Tumor Identifier Domain Tumor Identifier Location Malignant Neoplasm Description
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A domain that represents the data that uniquely identifies tumors._The site in or on the body at which the tumor identification test or result is performed or collected.:A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas._A written or verbal account, representation, statement, or explanation of something.

Property.preferredDefinition: A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas._A written or verbal account, representation, statement, or explanation of something.

Concepts.definition: A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.
A written or verbal account, representation, statement, or explanation of something.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: An organizational header for concepts representing mostly abstract entities.

Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The spread or migration of cancer cells from one part of the body (the organ in which it first appeared) to another. The secondary tumor contains cells that are like those in the original (primary) tumor.

Concepts.definition: The spread or migration of cancer cells from one part of the body (the organ in which it first appeared) to another. The secondary tumor contains cells that are like those in the original (primary) tumor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The spread of a malignant neoplasm to the lymph nodes.

Concepts.longName: Metastatic Malignant Neoplasm in the Lymph Nodes
Concepts.definition: The spread of a malignant neoplasm from its original site of growth to lymph nodes.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Concept annotation added for UPitt/TCGA.  Ylu, 02/24/2015.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Occurring first in time or sequence; original; of greatest rank or importance or value.

Concepts.definition: Occurring first in time or sequence; original; of greatest rank or importance or value.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

Concepts.definition: The site in or on the body at which the tumor identification test or result is performed or collected.

A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
